bibl.idno: The Philip S. Hench Walter Reed/Yellow Fever Collection [manuscript] / [collected by] Philip S. Hench ; HEALTHSCI MS-1.

bibl.title: Letter from Lillie W. Franck to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 7, 1944

div1.p: Franck sends Kean a completed manuscript for Hench [not enclosed]. In a second letter on the same page, dated February 8, 1944, Kean writes to Hench that the manuscript is enclosed. He mentions a newspaper account of the launch of a ship named for James Carroll.

div1.head: Letter from Lillie W. Franck to Jefferson Randolph Kean, February 7, 1944
div1.p:
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
PRESIDENT
COL. LUCIUS A. SALISBURY
M. C., N. Y. N. G.
S2 BROADWAY
NEW YORK 4, N. Y.
FIRST VICE-PRESIDENT
ASST. SURG. GEN. WARREN F. DRAFER
UNITED STATES PUBLIC HEALTH SERVICE
SECOND VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. EDGAR ERSKINE HUME
M. C., U. S. ARMY
THIRD VICE-PRESIDENT
COL. IRVIN ABELL
MED. RES., U. S. ARMY
FOURTH VICE-PRESIDENT
DR. MARTIN L. COOLEY
VETERANS' ADMINISTRATION
SECRETARY
COL. JAMES M. PHALEN
U. S. ARMY, RET.
EXECUTIVE SECRETARY
STUART E. WOMELDORPH
THE MILITARY SURGEON
EDITOR
COL. JAMES M. PHALEN
U. S. ARMY, RET.
ASS'T EDITOR
COMDR. ROST. C. RANSDELL
M. C., U. S. H. R.
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM
WASHINGTON 25, D. C.
February 7, 1944 FIFTH VICE-PRESIDENT
CAPT. ROBERT E. DUNCAN
M. C., U. S. NAVY
-----
AIR SERVICE SECTION
PRESIDENT
LT. COL. WILLIAM R. LOVELACE, II
M. C., U. S. ARMY
-----
DENTAL SECTION
PRESIDENT
BRIG. GEN. L. C. FAIRBANK
U. S. ARMY, RET.
-----
VETERINARY SECTION
PRESIDENT
LT. COL. O. E. McKIM
V. C. A. U. S.
Brig. General J. R. Kean, U.S. Army, Ret.,
2804 N. Street, N.W.,
Washington, D.C.
My dear General:

I am enclosing the completed manuscript for Colonel Hench ready to
mail to him, but left unsealed for you to enclose the papers you have for him.
He did not say anything to me about doing anything about Dr. Pinto's papers.
I am sorry I had to keep him waiting so long, but there seemed to be so many
things that would come up to take up my evenings, and that is the only time
I had to work on his manuscript. I want to thank you for your help.
With kindest regards to Mrs. Kean and yourself, I am

Sincerely yours,
Lillie W. Franck.
1237 - 18th St., N.E.

Here is the completed U. S. S.
at last, I have been over it all and think that
my answers are better for revision-
I hope you had a good trip and are now settled
down and at home on your job- Be sure to let me
know about my friend Gen. Ryan- diagnosis, prog-
nosis and his spirits- You will be having spring
down there in a few weeks- I saw in the paper
a day or two ago a notice of the launching in Baltimore
of a merchant ship named the James Carroll after him
Ac
K
of Yellow Fever fame- The lady who broke the bottle
of Champagne was Mrs. G. who Carroll of Washington
I am not certain of the two middle initials- I
think she must have been the wife of your friend
George! I intended to cut it out for you but did
not want to mutilate the paper until Mrs Kean
saw it and it got away from me- Did you ever
get to see Mrs. Stark? Did you ever get your copies
of the second printing of Truby's book? I have not
have any news of him since I saw you- will
pass it on when I get some-

I hope you have a good stenog. in that big hospital
and can dictate a few lines occasionally-
I must stop now and get this into the mail-
Mrs Kean sends cordial regards with mine
